message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Pyrazinamide can cause elevated liver enzymes as a side effect. Isoniazid can also cause hepatitis but usually at a later stage of treatment. Streptomycin and Ethambutol are not associated with liver toxicity.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Pyrazinamide is known to cause elevation in liver enzymes, especially in the first few weeks of therapy. Isoniazid is also known to cause hepatotoxicity, but usually after prolonged therapy. Streptomycin and Ethambutol are not known to cause liver toxicity.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Pyrazinamide is known to cause hepatotoxicity and can lead to elevated ALT and AST levels. Isoniazid is also hepatotoxic but is less likely to cause significant liver damage. Streptomycin and Ethambutol do not have hepatotoxic effects.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Pyrazinamide is known to cause hepatotoxicity and can elevate ALT and AST levels. Isoniazid can also cause drug-induced liver injury, but it is more commonly associated with elevated bilirubin levels. Streptomycin and Ethambutol are not known to cause liver function test elevation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Elevated AST and ALT levels suggest liver damage, and among the options, Pyrazinamide is the most common cause of drug-induced hepatitis. Isoniazid can also cause liver damage, but Pyrazinamide is more likely to cause elevations in AST and ALT levels. Streptomycin and Ethambutol do not cause liver toxicity.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Isoniazid and ethambutol are known to cause liver toxicity, but usually at higher doses or prolonged use. Streptomycin is an aminoglycoside antibiotic and does not affect the liver. Pyrazinamide, on the other hand, is known to cause hepatotoxicity, especially in patients with preexisting liver disease or alcoholism. Therefore, pyrazinamide is the most likely drug to have contributed to the elevated ALT and AST levels.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Pyrazinamide is known to cause hepatotoxicity, which can manifest as elevated ALT and AST levels. Isoniazid can also cause hepatotoxicity, but it is usually associated with increased bilirubin levels. Streptomycin and Ethambutol are not associated with hepatotoxicity.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the anti-tubercular drugs, Pyrazinamide is known to cause hepatotoxicity, with elevated liver enzymes alanine transaminase (ALT) and aspartate transaminase (AST). Isoniazid can also cause liver injury, but typically in a dose-dependent manner. Streptomycin and Ethambutol are not known to cause significant liver toxicity.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest tuberculosis and she was started on a drug regimen for it. Pyrazinamide can cause liver dysfunction and has been associated with elevated levels of ALT and AST. Isoniazid, Streptomycin, and Ethambutol are not known to cause liver dysfunction.
We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Pyrazinamide, among the other options, is known to cause hepatotoxicity, evidenced by elevated ALT and AST levels.
